Functions
A function is a set of set of statements that performs a task.
There are 2 main reasons for using functions instead of writing every program as big chunks of code:
  • Reusability: After defining a function, it can be used over and over easily. This lets programmers save significant amounts of time by reusing and sharing the same instructions without having to type them every time.
  • Abstraction: Using a function does not require the user to know how it works. They would just need to know how to invoke the function properly. The only time a developer needs to know how the function works is when they are either creating or modifying said function.
// Defining a function
function helloWorld() {
  alert( 'Hello, world!' );
}
// Invoking a function
helloWorld();
Arrays & Collections

Arrays are a special variable type that can hold more than one item at a time.

They are often used to store number sequences or collections of similar variables. They also make looping through similar variables significantly more accessible. In JavaScript, the items in an array can be different data types.

// Declaring an array
var colors = ["Pink", "Yellow", "Green"];

// Accessing the items
document.getElementById("apple").style.color = colors[2];
Conditional Structures
Conditional statements are used to perform tasks based on whether specific conditions are met or not. They are important tools for controlling the flow of the code. In JavaScript, there are three main types of conditionals:
  • Ternary Operator: The only operator that takes 3 operands and is used as a short version of an if-statement.
    • // Syntax: condition ? expr1 : expr2
'The apple is ' + (isRipe() ? 'Red' : 'Green');
  • If-statement: The most common of the conditional statements. 
    • // Syntax: if (condition) { statements1 } else { statements2 }
if (x > 5) {
 /* do the thing */
} else {
 /* do the other thing */
}
  • switch-statement: Used to check a single condition for several possibilities. 
    • switch(expression) {
  case p1:
    // statements1
    break;
  case p2:
  case p3:
    // statements2
    break;
  default:
    // all other situations;
    break;
}
